text:
I currently work on the GTM team at eBay for Payments as a content strategist and I work closely with two PMMs and one  of the people in charge of product experience.

At eBay, everyone has "ramps" which are how we contribute to the org, and it's intended to ensure there's no overlap or redundancy. Everyone is expected to be experts in their specific field.

My team does interface with external agencies and we all critique the creative, but that's in the capacity of making sure the explainer videos are understandable by the audience.

We don't touch our social media campaigns or other general marketing activities directly. We do however collaborate with the divisions and gather information.

When I was at Airbnb, we had a very similar model. I occasionally helped other teams but it required approval from my manager and the department head.

So overall, I've found that in large orgs, the model is typically you're expected to be an expert in your area, and you need to trust your colleagues to be experts in their roles.

text: I agree with Charles's last statement ^. The best working relationships require a certain amount of trust in expertise. I work at a mid-size company, and our PMMs are expected to know a lot about the product, the people who use them, and how those people are using them. Oftentimes, that bleeds into them knowing a lot about digital and having comments about copy and content (things like, 'that's a strange word to use, because the target audience doesn't necessarily speak like that'), but I wouldn't say our marketing team expects them to know content marketing basics or how campaigns work, etc. Hope you can find something that works for your team! It can def be a challenge.

text: PMMs come in all shapes and sizes. When I was one, my background was product and I had no awareness of any of your bullets. Since pivoting to content marketing, I do. But, I wouldn't *expect* this of any PMM I work with.
